title: French I
description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of French to explore the basic features of the French language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written French through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of French grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: (1) master the basic communication skills such as greeting somebody (2) exchanging basic personal information with someone in a social gathering (3) describing an object or a person, shopping.
syllabus: FREN1000      Course Content: The course will cover the following 7 lessons of the textbook Le nouveau Taxi 1: lessons 1 – 7     Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Leçon 1 Bienvenue! (Welcome!) - Greeting (1) - Introducing oneself - Inquiring / Giving information:  name & nationality - Conjugation: - être / - s’appeler - Subject pronouns’ gender:   masculine vs feminine (il vs. elle)  - The question word qui - Elision    Leçon 2 Qui est-ce ? (Who is it?) - Introducing someone:  - first name , family name - profession - address: city & country  - Noun group (1):  - definite article + noun  - Noun’s gender: masculine vs. feminine - Adjective’s agreement: in gender & number - preposition + country/city   Leçon 3 Ça va bien? (How are you?) - Giving information about a person: - name, age, profession, address & phone number - greetings (2) - asking / giving / understanding basic personal information - Numbers 21 - 69   - Irregular Verbs: aller, avoir - Possessive adjectives (1) - Indefinite articles  - Interrogative adjectives (1)   Leçon 4 Correspond@nce (Correspondence) - Revision: lessons 1 - 3. Talk about taste and preferences - “La francophonie” (French speaking countries)    Leçon 5 Trouvez l’objet (Find the object)  - Describing a room and its objects - Indicating the location of an object - Locating an object - Prepositions & prepositional phrases of place - Adverbs of place - Definite & Indefinite articles (2)  - The French idiom: Il y a … - Sentence structure with Qu’est-ce que …   Leçon 6 Portrait-robot (Photofit) - Describing people & objects - Colors - Talking about color - Stressed pronouns (1) - The verb avoir - The negative particles ne … pas - Adjectives’ agreement (with noun or pronoun) - Possessive Adjectives (2)   Leçon 7  Shopping - Describing objects (2) - Asking price - Describing an object - Clothes shopping - Filling an order-form - Numbers : 70 - 1000 - Question word: comment, combien  - Interrogative adjectives (2)  - Demonstrative adjectives

title: Made in France
description: This course is designed to present the French society and culture from a cross-cultural perspective. We will particularly examine the aspects of behavior, attitudes and customs of the French in modern France, as well as their image in the world.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to: (1) Analyze the main cultural traits of French. (2) Globally understand the culture of contemporary France and to take a critical look on it.

title: French II
description: Building on the knowledge acquired in FREN1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in French in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of French culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in French while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: (1) master the basic communication skills such as asking for direction or ordering food at a restaurant (2) be able to traveling in a French speaking country, buying train or airplane tickets  (3) talking about one’s daily activities and habits, relating past events.
syllabus: FREN1002      Course syllabus: The course will cover the following 8 lessons of the textbook Le Nouveau TAXI 1: lessons 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 18, 19.       Lesson   Speech acts   Grammar    Leçon 10:  Pour aller au Louvre? (How to go to the Louvre ?)  - Asking the way: Direction & means of transportation. - Sentence structure: The imperative mood. - Prepositions: - the contracted forms au , du - à & en + means of transportation. - Adverb of place: y   Leçon 11: Voyages, voyages (Travel, travel)  - Situating a place on a map. - Giving advice. - Expression: - C’est + Noun Group - C’est + Adjective - C’est + Adverbial of place - The Subject pronoun on. - Prepositions of place.   Leçon 13:  Vous partez quand ? (When are you leaving? )  - Hours & Dates - Polite questions. - Question with - Quand … ? - Quelle heure est-il ? - Verb : partir (present tense)   Leçon 14:  À Genève (At Geneva)  - Jobs and Professions. - Asking for information. - Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun. - Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun.- Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun.   Leçon 15:  Le dimanche matin (Sunday morning)  - What one is doing. - What one is used to do. - Sports. - Verbs: lire, écrire (present tense) - Verbes pronominaux (Part I) - Le dimanche / dimanche prochain.   Leçon 17:  Mardi gras  - Expressions of need. - Talking about habitude. - Expressions of quantity - Partitive articles: du, de la, de l’ - Verbs: - boire, acheter & manger (present tense)   Leçon 18:  Une bonne journée (A good day)             - Talking about past events (I) - Giving personal opinion. - Paying compliments. - The tense Passé composé (I) with auxiliary verb avoir. - Basic forms of the past participle in French. - Agreement of Adjective : beau   Leçon 19 :  Où sont-ils allés ? (Where have they been ?)  - Talking about past events (II) - Expressions of duration. - The tense Passé composé (II) with auxiliary verb être. - Markers of time.

title: French III
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken FREN3000,3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: FREN2000 (1002) or FREN2050 (1010)
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
outcome: After taking this course, the student is expected to be able to express his/her opinion about simple issues or to express objections, to give advice or to make suggestions. He/she would know how to behave and interact in a situation related to work such as looking for a job, asking for information about a job advertisement, attending a job interview, speaking with colleagues, etc. On the other hand, the student should be capable to speak about holidays, activities during days off and leisure time.
syllabus: FREN2001      Course Content: The course will cover the following 6 lessons of the textbook Le nouveau TAXI 1: lessons 21 – 27    Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Leçon 21 C’est interdit! (It is prohibited!) - Asking for permission: - Accepting / Refusing - Expressions of prohibition  - Verb: pouvoir + verb 2 - The indirect object pronouns - Imperative + Negative    Leçon 22 Petites annonces. (Classified.) - Talking about capability & will  - Talking about obligation - Verbs: vouloir, savoir - The impersonal verb:  falloir : Il faut - Expressing future events : futur proche   Leçon 23 Qu’est-ce qu’on lui offre? (What should we give her?) - Making suggestions : - Accepting / Refusing  - Verbs: connaître - Direct object pronouns. - Indirect object pronouns.    Leçon 25 Enquête. (Report.)  -Expressing likes & dislikes - Expressing frequency - Expressing intensity - Pronouns: en, ça - The negative form:  ne … plus    Leçon 26 Quitter Paris. (Leaving Paris.) - Expressing opinions - Expressing objections   - The question word:    pourquoi - The conjunctive phrase: parce que / parce qu’… - Adv. of intensity + Adj.: assez / trop + adjective - Expression of quantity + Noun : assez de / trop de + Noun  - Adj.: Tout / toute / tous / tous - Pronouns: tous / toutes    Leçon 27  Vivement les vacances! (Can’t wait for holiday!) - Expressing appreciation / depreciation - Giving advice   - Verbes pronominaux: *se lever. *position of the reflexive pronoun in imperative mood

title: Sounds of French
description: This course is an introduction to the phonetic system of the French language. Illustrations and examples will be taken from modern spoken French. Similarities and differences to other languages will also be examined when appropriate. Students learning French are encouraged to take this course.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: (1)be able to use the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and the IPA symbols provided in dictionaries; (2)understand, compare and hypothesize on the production of speech sounds (place of articulation, differences and common points…); (3)understand and describe the rhythmic groups and intonation patterns of modern French; (4)be able to pronounce/read out modern French and analyze phenomenon of spoken French; (5)be able to play with words sonority and create short rhymes/ poems/ songs…
syllabus: • Types of Speech sound in modern French (International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)): - Vowel,  - Consonant,  - Semi-vowel, - Phonemes, - Distinctive features and minimal pair.   • French Syllable: - Syllable structures (open syllable/close syllable), - Syllabification and syllable boundary, - Vowel clusters/Consonant clusters, - Final letter: final consonant; final /e/ (Schwa [ә]).   • French Syllable & Rhythmic groups: - Pronunciation of numbers, - Enchaînement, - Liaison: obligatoire, interdite, facultative, - Elision, - [ә] caduc.   • Intonation patterns: - Pitch, - Stress, - Duration.   • If time allows: - Expressive intonation patterns, - Usual foreign words.  All through the term, spoken and written French will be used (dialogues, rhymes, poem, prose…).

description: This course is designed to introduce students to some most representative figures in French literature. Emphasis is to be placed on the critical and analytical reading of their major works in English version. No knowledge of French is required.

title: French IV
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken FREN3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: FREN2001
description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written French. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.
outcome: The student should be able to tell about his/her childhood and any other story in the past tense. Moreover, he/she will be expected to be able to understand an event mentioned in a newspaper or on the radio and to report it again. In the end, he/she should be capable to make plans, to propose conditions and to express intention and certitude as well as eventuality.

title: French V

description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in French with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.

title: French VI
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken FREN3051 (3010).;2. Prerequisite: FREN3001.
description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous French language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from A2 to B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of French. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of French and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the French-speaking societies.
outcome: Students will learn how to :  • gives advises and suggestions.  • express opinions and feelings.  • talk about leisure activities and justify the choice. • talk about a trip and past experience.

title: French Conversation
description: This course aims to enhance students’ oral communication skills in French. Through selected student-oriented stimuli and topics related to social issues and contemporary affairs, students will practice the expression and exchange of personal views and ideas. Classroom activities may include in-class activities such as dialogue, role-play, narration, speech, group discussion, debate and multimedia activities. Emphasis will be placed on oral practice and an interactive learning environment with a view to helping students build confidence and develop fluency in using the language, to speak spontaneously in social interaction and acquire conversational techniques commonly used in a French-speaking environment.

title: French Reading and Creative Writing
description: This course is designed for students who study French and want to enhance their reading and writing skills through literary texts and excerpts. The emphasis will be placed on the reading of French texts and poems which lead to creative writings in French. The objective of the course is to equip students with language keys to comprehend the texts and subsequently produce creative texts in French. All texts are in French.

title: Business French I
description: This course is designed to introduce and train in active practice in a wide range of business related dialogues, as well as to acquire the basic skills of business terminology through the reading of short commercial documents.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: - to be able to use common communication professional tools. - make individual projects or team project in professional situation. - acquire stronger confidence to talk in front of formal audience. - describe and compare companies’ organizational structure. Students will be given tools to speak about various topics such as Motivation letter, CV Video, economic situation, formal company documents, professional presentation, job interview, French around the world.

M1 p.7-18 - Professional contacts- Introducing yourself- Describing a product- Understanding a product dealing network.  - Greetings.- Using  “tu/vous”.  Export French Textiles.   Leçon 2La communication professionnelle(Professional communication)M2 p.19-30 - Making a phone call and leaving a message.- Confirming order with a formal mail.- Making an appointment - Business Trip communication- French companies Retain your customers.   Leçon 3Partez en déplacement !(Business trip!)U4 p.59-73 - Choosing an hotel and book a room- Choosing and buy a train/airplane ticket- Finding the hotel on the map/ on the road - Phone in France.- Transportations in France.  Professional fees reimbursement.   Leçon 4La visite d’un client(A customer’s visit!)M3 p.31-42 - Welcoming a client.- Company introduction/visit.- Creating and managing a planning.- Speaking in public / holding a meeting.  - Meeting in France.- French company organization.  TV investigation on French major companies.   Leçon 5Trouver un emploi (Finding a Job)U8 p.126-139 - Describing a job.- Describing job competences and professional skills for a job.- Talking about job experiences.- Negotiating job conditions. - Job environment in France.  Cover letter. Leçon 9Le compte est bon(Total is good)M6 p.67-77 - Understanding an invoice.- Making a phone call for late payment.- Understanding different payments tool.- Understanding a company balance sheet. - French compagnies types (EURL, SARL, SA, SNC, GIE, SEM). “Rationalize the invoice : rationaliser la facturation”.

title: French III & IV
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken FREN2001,3000 (2002),3001,3002 or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: FREN2000(1002) or 2050(1010)
description: This is a summer intensive French language course, covering the full syllabus of FREN2001 and 3000.
outcome: The student should be able to express his/her opinion about simple issues or to express objections, to give advice or to make suggestions. He/she would learn how to behave and interact in a situation related to work such as looking for a job, asking for information about a job advertisement, attending a job interview, speaking with colleagues, etc., and also be capable to speak about holidays, activities during days off and leisure time, to tell about his/her childhood and any other story in the past tense. Moreover, he/she will be expected to be able to understand an event mentioned in a newspaper or on the radio and to report it again. In the end, he/she should be capable to make plans, to propose conditions and to express intention and certitude as well as eventuality.
syllabus: FREN2010      Course syllabus: The course will cover the following 16 lessons of the textbook LE NOUVEAU TAXI 1: lessons 21 - 36.       Lesson   Speech acts   Grammar    Leçon 21 C’est interdit ! (It is prohibited!) - Asking for permission: - Accepting / Refusing - Expressions of prohibition - Verb: pouvoir + verb 2 - The indirect object pronouns - Imperative + Negative   Leçon 22 Petites annonces. (Classified.)    - Talking about capability & will  - Talking about obligation - Verbs: vouloir, savoir - The impersonal verb:    falloir : Il faut - Expressing future events : futur proche   Leçon 23 Qu’est-ce qu’on lui offre ? (What should we give her?)    - Making suggestions :   - Accepting / Refusing - Verbs: connaître - Direct object pronouns. - Indirect object pronouns.   Leçon 24 Le candidat idéal. (The best applicant.)    - Giving advice & guidance  - Revision - Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun.- Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun.   Leçon 25 Enquête. (Report.)     -Expressing likes & dislikes - Expressing frequency - Expressing intensity - Pronouns: en, ça - The negative form:    ne … plus   Leçon 26 Quitter Paris.    (Leaving Paris.)    - Expressing opinions - Expressing objections - The question word:    pourquoi - The conjunctive phrase:   parce que / parce qu’… - Adv. of intensity + Adj.:   assez / trop + adjective - Expression of quantity + Noun :   assez de / trop de + Noun  - Adj.: Tout / toute / tous / tous - Pronouns: tous / toutes    Leçon 27  Vivement les vacances ! (Can’t wait for holiday!) - Expressing appreciation / depreciation - Giving advice - Verbes pronominaux:   *se lever.   *position of the reflexive pronoun in imperative mood   Leçon 28 Les Français en vacances. (French people on holidays) - Activities on holiday  - Revision      Leçon 29 Enfant de la ville (City Kid) - Talking about a recent events  - Talking about events and habits in the past - Passé récent : venir de + inf. - Form of the imparfait tense   Leçon 30 Fait divers. (News in Brief) - Talking about events and states of mind in the past. - Describing circumstances. - Form and use of passé composé and imparfait - Differences about the two tenses.   Leçon 31 Ma première histoire d’amour (My first Love Story) - Locating events in the time. - Expressing purposes : Goals & objectives.  - Dates, moment and duration. - The use of the preposition pour + inf. - Past participles.   Leçon 32 La 2CV… et autres symboles. (2CV car… and other symbols) Revision       Leçon 33 Beau Fixe (Nice Weather) - Talking about weather. - Expressing eventuality & certitude. - Tense : Le futur (simple)     Leçon 34 Projets d’avenir (Projects for the Future) - Making projects. - Locating events in the time.   - Tenses for denoting future events : présent, futur proche, futur simple   Adverbs & adverbial phrases of time for future events.         Leçon 35  Envie de changement (Willing to Change)                              - Making conditions. - Expressing one’s intention. - Hypothesis & condition with:      si + present, future - Moment: quand + future tense. - Other irregular verbs in future tense.     Leçon 36 Le pain, mangez-en ! (Eat Bread!) Revision

requirements:

description: This course aims to strengthen and expand students’ language skills like speaking, listening, writing and reading. This will allow students to have better understanding of French culture and current French societal tendency. It places special emphasis on conversational fluency, grammatical accuracy and vocabulary acquisition. The course is mainly designed from several awarded shorts films and one movie. outcome: After taking this course student are expected to  • engage and participate in oral discussion on diverse topics. • gain the cultural knowledge and vocabulary on these topics.  • develop the ability to defend their opinion. • Improve the ability to understand spoken French language and to reuse them.

title: Special Topics in French
description: This course aims at furthering students' understanding of selected area(s) of French language, literature or culture. Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.

title: French Through Literature
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): FREN3000,3050,3001,3002,3051 or equivalent competence;Not for students who have taken FREN3100 in 2016-17
description: This course aims at enhancing the student’s command in reading and writing of French through the study of French literary works. Through activities such as creative writing, drama performance, role-playing and group discussion, students will familiarize themselves with different literary forms (poems, novels, plays, etc.) in French. The course also aims at enriching student’s general knowledge about French literary culture and allowing them to explore the writings of selected famous French authors in the specific context of their historical/biographical and cultural background. Students will be exposed to selected works through multimedia such as movies, voice recordings, songs and visual illustrations.
outcome: At the completion of this course the students will be able to : • Write in French in a creative and more elaborative way to express their ideas. • Have a better reading ability in French. • Recognize the main elements of literary genres such as poetry, novel and plays and assess their significance. • Place authors and literary text in their cultural and historical context and be able to analyze texts from different genres. • Students will be able to comprehend and respond with an enhanced command of French in reading and writing and a heightened cultural awareness.
syllabus: FREN3110        Unit   Objectives   Themes   Culture   Unit I La Poésie pour parler de soi. (Introducing oneself in a form of poetry) -Introducing and writing about oneself through diverse poetical forms. -Exploring and getting familiar with a variety of forms of poems. -Writing by imitating or by following precise instructions. -Having some knowledge about History of poetry and some major French poets. -Developping a personal understanding of some selected major French Poems. -Classifying poetry in historical context. -Likes and dislikes. -Hobbies. -Childhood and adulthood. -Family. -Wishes and hopes. -Time.         -20th century Surrealism.  -Calligraphy in poetry. -Popular and famous poems and poets of the XIX and XXth century.  -Classic poems from Jean de La Fontaine (XVIIe).   Unit II Le Roman pour évoquer la rencontre.  (Exploring Novel through scenes of encounter)  -Reading and understanding dialogues. -Writing a narrative text.  -Relating past experiences. -Creating characters and write a text about their first encounter. -Accepting, refusing a making proposals. -Defining words. -Expressing feelings. -Love and friendship. -The issue of being  different/tolerance. -Childhood. -Family. -XXe Major Novels such as The Little Prince by Saint Exupery or L’Amant by Marguerite Duras. -Discovering Exercises of Styles by Raymond Queneau. -XIXe Romantism (Victor Hugo’s Notre Dame) and Realism (Guy de Maupassant’s short story Simon’s father).   Unit III Le Théâtre : l’interaction et la communication.   (Exploring interaction and communication issue through theater through plays) -Exploring several genre such as comedy and tragedy and the theater of the Absurd.   -Discovering the characteristics and specificity of a theatrical text and its representation on stage.    -Analyzing and performing a passage of a play related to the issue of communication.  -By imitation or by following precise instruction, writing a theatrical text and perform it.  -Understanding the issue of some scenes taken from various French plays and deepen their understanding.  -Comic situation due to misunderstandings.  -Education. -Morals and family matters. -XXe Theater of the Absurd : The Lesson by Ionesco, The Misunderstanding by Albert Camus, Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett. -XXe Antigone by Jean Anouilh. -XIXe Dindon by George Feydeau. -XVIIe Molière’s The Middle class Gentlemen.
